titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson Washington Go-Go collection, 1978-2008 MS2177
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson Washington Go-Go collection
did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, promotional materials, clippings, interviews, photographs, slides, audio cassette tapes, electronic records, and other materials. The material dates from 1978-2008, and was collected by Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson in the course of their research on go-go music. The materials document the evolution of go-go and the cultural and political role of go-go in Washington, D.C. Go-go originated in Washington, D.C. in the 1970s. It is a subgenre of funk, and is characterized by continuous complex rhythm arrangements and crowd call and response. The term "go-go" refers both to the style of music and the venue in which music is performed.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson Washington Go-Go collection, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson in 2002. A second donation by Kip Lornell came to the library in 2014.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Christopher "Kip" Lornell (b. 1953) and Charles Stephenson are the authors of the book "The Beat: Go-Go's Fusion of Funk and Hip-Hop." Lornell is a noted ethnomusicologist, and a professor in The George Washington University's Department of Music. He received his Bachelor of Science in Cultural Sciences in 1975 from State University of New York Empire State College, his Master of Arts in Folklore in 1976 from University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and his Ph. D. in Ethnomusicology (Regional American Music) in 1983 from University of Memphis. Stephenson is a cultural and political activist in Washington, D.C., and a strong advocate for go-go music. He was the manager of the influential go-go group Experience Unlimited. He works as an associate in the management consulting firm of Dellums & Associates.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, promotional materials, clippings, interviews, photographs, slides, audio cassette tapes, electronic records, and other materials. The material dates from 1978-2008, and was collected by Kip Lornell and Charles Stephenson in the course of their research on go-go music. The materials document the evolution of go-go and the cultural and political role of go-go in Washington, D.C. Go-go originated in Washington, D.C. in the 1970s. It is a subgenre of funk, and is characterized by continuous complex rhythm arrangements and crowd call and response. The term "go-go" refers both to the style of music and the venue in which music is performed. In the 1980's, go-go became associated with drugs and violence, and many go-go clubs were closed in Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: Papers, Images, Audiocassettes, Electronic records and 2014 donation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, promotional materials, clippings, interviews, and other materials. The material dates from 1978-2002. The documents contain information about go-go music, performers, and venues, as well as the media perception of go-go. Of particular interest is a transcript of a conference held in 2000, entitled "Gimme That Beat! Twenty-five Years of Go-Go," at which both Lornell and Stephenson spoke. The series also contains interviews with go-go musicians, flyers and promotional materials from go-go shows, go-go magazines, and documents related to the effort to disassociate go-go from violence.

did.unittitle: Folk Arts Program--D.C. Commission on the Arts
"Gimme That Beat! Twenty-five Years of Go-Go" Conference transcript [1/2]
"Gimme That Beat! Twenty-five Years of Go-Go" Conference transcript [2/2]
Humanities Council of Washington, D.C. Grant

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains color photographs, black-and-white photographs, and color slides of go-go performers, shows, and events. The images are undated and most are unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audiocassette tapes dating from 1998 to 2001. The cassettes contain interviews with musicians, filmmakers, and other prominent figures in the world of go-go music; a recording of a conference on the subject of go-go; and recordings of go-go shows.

did.unittitle: Funk, Stephenson / Lornell, Darnell and Andre
Funk, Kip, Charles / Darnell, Andre (Rare Essence)
Legends Feat. Lil Benny / Legend Nite Club
Andre Lucas / Lonnie Johnson Self Esteem

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of floppy disks dating from 1998 to 2000. The disks consist of word processing files in various formats containing transcripts of interviews with musicians and prominent figures in the world of go-go music.

did.unittitle: Gogo interview--Rene Dickerson and Funky D

physdesc.extent: 2 document boxes, 1 slim document box and 1 flat box

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Paper records and Cassettes, VHS, and CDs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publicity materials both from clubs and from media outlets, programs, correspondence, VHS, audiocassettes and cds of musical acts. The records are an addition to the previous donation and cover the same topics. These records date from 1982-2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains articles, magazines, publicity, programs and correspondence related to the Go-Go music scene in Washington DC. The material dates from 1984-2003.

did.unittitle: Portfolio for assessment of prior experiential learning by Mary Carlson and Charles Stephenson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains cassettes, VHS tapes, and CDs of Go Go musicians both albums and recordings of events. These date from 1982-2008.
